awd_titl_txt: Molecular mechanisms underlying temperature modulation of plant immunity
awd_abstract_narration:
Broader significance
Plant immune responses are greatly modulated by environmental signals including temperature, and this modulation is an adaptive mechanism for a balanced environmental response and plant growth. There is limited knowledge on how temperature is perceived and how it regulates plant immune responses. This project will identify targets of temperature on immune responses and reveal major strategies plants use to tune immunity to temperature. This project will enhance the prediction power of climate change on plant growth and defense and will provide guidance in breeding crop plants that have a balanced growth and defense for the changing environment. The project will integrate education with research for undergraduate students including minorities at and outside Cornell through various programs including NSF Plant Genome REU Site. One of the four aims of the project will be conducted mostly by undergraduates. This project will also provide a broad training to a postdoctoral fellow and a graduate student in research and teaching assisted by the NSF ?Center for the integration of research, teaching, and learning? program. Discoveries generated from this project will be disseminated through journal publications, conference presentations and classroom teaching, thus contributing to the advancement of science.

Technical Description
The goal of this project is to further elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying temperature modulation of immune receptor R-mediated immune responses. Earlier studies revealed that R proteins could function as temperature sensors and deficiency of abscisic acid antagonizes the high temperature effects on R proteins. This project will first further reveal how temperature and abscisic acid regulate the activity of R proteins to affect immunity. This will be achieved by dissecting the regulation through genetic screens using Arabidopsis autoimmune plants. Mutants with altered temperature sensitivity in immune responses will be isolated and cloned, and the mode of gene action will be investigated. This project will also reveal the genetic basis of variation of temperature sensitivity of immunity in natural populations. This will be achieved by surveying wild Arabidopsis accessions for their temperature sensitivities in disease resistance. Major loci determining the temperature sensitivity will be isolated. With identification of mode of regulation of R proteins by temperature and ABA as well as major strategies in tuning immunity to temperature signals, this project will reveal new mechanisms of signal sensing and signal integration and provide strategies to generate plants with optimal responses to a changing environment.

por.por_cntn:
Temperature has a large impact on plant immune responses, but there is limited knowledge on how changes in temperature affect plant immune responses. In this project, we investigated the impact of temperature on multiple layers and branches of plant immunity and identified several molecular components connecting temperature and these immunity systems.

Major findings

1) Natural variations of temperature-sensitivity of plant immunity

We assessed natural variations of thermo-sensitivity of disease resistance of Arabidopsis thaliana to a virulent pathogen strain of Pseudomonas syringae. Pathogen growth was assayed on over 70 Arabidopsis accessions at three temperatures:16C (moderately low), 22C, and 28C (moderately high). Genome wide association study (GWAS) on thermo-sensitivity of pathogen growth identified a few quantitative trait loci (QTL). Causal genes for two QTLs were verified to affect plant immunity in a temperature-dependent manner. One encodes a transferase that is potentially involved in GSH metabolism and the other encodes a lipid body associated protein. Further studies of these two previously uncharacterized genes will reveal the function of new metabolites and lipid body in temperature-regulated plant immunity.

2) Nuclear pore complex and temperature-sensitivity of plant immunity

We assessed the function of subunits of nuclear pore complex (Nup) in the outer ring in immunity at 22C and 28C. These NUPs were found to have a temperature-dependent function in one or multiple development and/or immune responses. Some Nups are required for nuclear-cytosol shuttling of proteins/mRNAs and transcriptome programming especially at elevated temperature. These studies indicate that nuclear pore function is dynamic and is likely less robust under elevated temperatures, which might contribute to temperature sensitivity of plant immunity. 

3) impact of low temperature on plant immunity

The effects of moderate low temperature (16C) on plant immunity and pathogen virulence were assayed in Arabidopsis thaliana-Pseudomonas syringae system. Mutants defective in four hormone signaling sectors were used to reveal contributions of salicylic acid (SA), ethylene and jasmonic acid to disease resistance under different temperatures. We found that salicylic acid pathway is essential for low temperature enhancement of plant immunity. The effect of ethylene and jasmonic acid on immunity is mediated by SA. In addition, multiple components in the SA pathway are induced by low temperature and they are repressed by the transcription factor EIN3 in the ethylene response pathway. Therefore, low temperature enhances plant immunity through the SA pathway which is balanced by ethylene repression.

4) High temperature effect on stomatal immunity

Elevated temperature had been shown to inhibit to inhibit intracellular receptor NLR mediated apoplastic defense but enhances PAMP triggered immunity. We tested the effect of elevated temperature on stomatal immunity which is the stomatal closure in response to pathogen Pseudomonas syringae. While Arabidopsis plants closed their stomata upon detecting pathogen at both 22C and 28C, the closure was slower at 28C compared to 22C. In contrast, stomatal closure in response to ABA and SA was quicker at 28C compared to 22C. Therefore, elevated temperature slows down stomatal immunity.

5) Connection of stomatal immunity and apoplastic immunity with NLR activation

The opposite effect of NLR activation on stomatal immunity and apoplastic immunity was revealed during the study of autoimmune mutants. We generated chimera plants to activate NLR in guard cells and non-guard cells, respectively, to decipher the connections of these two immune responses. We found that NLR activation has both cell autonomous and cell non-autonomous function in stomatal and apoplastic immunities. This study thus reveals that NLR activation has a differential effect on immunity in a cell type specific matter, which adds another layer of immune regulation with spatial information.

6) Involvement of a cytokinin transporter in plant immunity

In a genetic screen for mutants with an altered temperature-sensitivity in immunity, we identified a transporter of cytokinin. We showed that this transporter as well as cytokinin are positive regulators of plant immunity, and this regulation is through the expression of NLR genes.

Impact of the findings

The above findings have significant impacts on the fields of plant immunity and plant temperature responses. 1) They have expanded the knowledge in temperature modulation of plant immunity at the molecular level. 2) They have furthered the understanding of the function and regulation of plant intracellular receptor NLR genes. 3) They have initiated the use of natural variations to investigate the environmental modulation of plant immunity.

This project has led to 13 research articles published in major journals in the field of plant biology. It has also supported research of approximately 10 people including postdoc fellows, graduate students and undergraduate students. This project has therefore contributed to the training of the next generation scientists.
